messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
> Sent: Thursday, October 16, 2003 6:50 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>
> Here's an example of what I mean:
>
> Let's assume we have class MyClass that implements interface
> MyInterface, with methods:
> public int x(){
> // return an answer based on y() and z()
> }
> private int y() {...}
> private int z() {...}
>
> And Interface MyInterface with method:
> public int x()


In your example, shouldn't y() and z() be protected instead of public or
private? This way clients can still override y() and z(), and call them
from the subclass, but they can not be invoked from outside the class.

Keeping this on topic, the protected methods shouldn't be very difficult
to test. The test can create a MockMyClass that overrides y() and z()
but change the modifier from protected to public.

Something like this:

public class MyClass
{
public MyClass()
{
super();
}

public int x()
{
return y() + z();
}

protected int y()
{
return 8;
}

protected int z()
{
return 73;
}
}

Use MockMyClass in the test to test y and z instead of MyClass.

public class MockMyClass extends MyClass
{
public MockMyClass()
{
super();
}

public int y()
{
return super.y();
}

public int z()
{
return super.z();
}
}

MyClass2 could look something like this:
public class MyClass2 extends MyClass
{
public MyClass2()
{
super();
}

protected int q()
{
return 23;
}

public int x()
{
return y() + z() + q();
}
}

Kris
